010package imagingbook.common.geometry.mappings.linear;
011
012import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d;
013import imagingbook.common.geometry.basic.Pnt2d.PntDouble;
014import imagingbook.common.geometry.fitting.points.ProjectiveFit2d;
015import imagingbook.common.geometry.mappings.Jacobian;
016import imagingbook.common.math.Arithmetic;
017import imagingbook.common.math.Matrix;
018import imagingbook.common.math.PrintPrecision;
019
020
021/**
022 * <p>
023 * This class represents a projective transformation in 2D (also known as a
024 * "homography"). It can be specified uniquely by four pairs of corresponding
025 * points. It can be assumed that every instance of this class is indeed a
026 * projective mapping. See Secs. 21.1.4 and 21.3.1 of [1] for details.
027 * </p>
028 * <p>
029 * [1] W. Burger, M.J. Burge, <em>Digital Image Processing &ndash; An
030 * Algorithmic Introduction</em>, 3rd ed, Springer (2022).
031 * </p>
032 * 
033 *  @author WB
034 */
035public class ProjectiveMapping2D extends LinearMapping2D implements Jacobian {
036        
037        //  static methods -----------------------------------------------------
038        
039        /**
040         * Creates a projective 2D mapping from two sequences of corresponding points.
041         * If 4 point pairs are specified, the mapping is exact, otherwise a
042         * minimum least-squares fit is calculated.
043         * @param P the source points
044         * @param Q the target points
045         * @return a new projective mapping for the two point sets
046         */
047        public static ProjectiveMapping2D fromPoints(Pnt2d[] P, Pnt2d[] Q) {
048                ProjectiveFit2d fit = new ProjectiveFit2d(P, Q);
049                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(fit.getTransformationMatrix());
050        }
051

094//              if (Arithmetic.isZero(S)) {

099//              double a00 = x1 - x0 + a20 * x1;
100//              double a01 = x3 - x0 + a21 * x3;
101//              double a02 = x0;

103//              double a11 = y3 - y0 + a21 * y3;

105//              return new ProjectiveMapping2D(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12, a20, a21);
106//      }
107        
108//      /**

110//       * @param p0 point 0 of source quad P

113//       * @param p3 point 3 of source quad P

178//      }
179        
180        //  constructors -----------------------------------------------------
181        
182        /**
183         * Creates the identity mapping.
184         */
185        public ProjectiveMapping2D() {
186                super();
187        }
188        
189        /**
190         * Creates a projective mapping from a transformation matrix A,
191         * of arbitrary size. All relevant elements of A are inserted into
192         * actual 3x3 transformation matrix, except element (2,2) which
193         * is ignored and always set to 1 (to keep the transformation projective).
194         * If A is larger than 3 x 3, the remaining elements are ignored.
195         * 
196         * @param A a transformation matrix of arbitrary size
197         */
198        public ProjectiveMapping2D(double[][] A) {
199                //this(new LinearMapping2D(A));
200                super(extractProjectiveMatrix(A));
201        }
202        
203        private static double[][] extractProjectiveMatrix(double[][] A) {
204                double[][] M = Matrix.idMatrix(3);
205                final int m = Math.min(3, A.length);    // max. 3 rows
206                for (int i = 0; i < m; i++) {
207                        final int n = Math.min(3, A[i].length); // max. 3 columns
208                        for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) {
209                                M[i][j] = A[i][j];
210                        }
211                }
212                M[2][2] = 1;
213                return M;
214        }
215
216        
217        /**
218         * Creates a projective mapping from the specified matrix elements.
219         * @param a00 matrix element A_00
220         * @param a01 matrix element A_01
221         * @param a02 matrix element A_02
222         * @param a10 matrix element A_10
223         * @param a11 matrix element A_11
224         * @param a12 matrix element A_12
225         * @param a20 matrix element A_20
226         * @param a21 matrix element A_21
227         */
228        public ProjectiveMapping2D(
229                        double a00, double a01, double a02, 
230                        double a10, double a11, double a12, 
231                        double a20, double a21) {
232                super(a00, a01, a02, a10, a11, a12, a20, a21, 1);
233        }
234        
235        /**
236         * Creates a projective mapping from any linear mapping.
237         * The transformation matrix gets normalized to a22 = 1.
238         * @param m a linear mapping
239         */
240        public ProjectiveMapping2D(LinearMapping2D m) {
241                this(m.normalize());
242        }
243        
244        /**
245         * Creates a projective mapping from an existing instance.
246         * @param m a projective mapping
247         */
248        public ProjectiveMapping2D(ProjectiveMapping2D m) {
249                //this(m.getTransformationMatrix());
250                this(m.a00, m.a01, m.a02, m.a10, m.a11, m.a12, m.a20, m.a21);
251        }
252        
253        // ----------------------------------------------------------
254        
255        /**
256         * Concatenates this mapping A with another linear mapping B and returns
257         * a new mapping C, such that C(x) = B(A(x)).
258         * @param B the second mapping
259         * @return the concatenated mapping
260         */
261        public ProjectiveMapping2D concat(ProjectiveMapping2D B) {
262                LinearMapping2D C = LinearMapping2D.concatenate(B, this);
263                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(C);
264        }
265        
266        /**
267         * {@inheritDoc}
268         * @return a new projective mapping
269         */
270        @Override
271        public ProjectiveMapping2D duplicate() {
272                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(this);
273        }
274        
275        /**
276         * {@inheritDoc}
277         * Note that the inverse A' of a projective transformation matrix A is again a linear transformation
278         * but its a'2' element is generally not 1. Scaling A' to A'' = A' / a22' yields a projective transformation
279         * that reverses A. While A * A' = I, the result of A * A'' is a scaled identity matrix.
280         * @return the inverse projective transformation
281         */
282        @Override
283        public ProjectiveMapping2D getInverse() {
284                return new ProjectiveMapping2D(super.getInverse());
285        }
286        
287        @Override
288        public double[][] getJacobian(Pnt2d xy) {
289                // see Baker 2003 "20 Years" Part 1, Eq. 99 (p. 46)
290                final double x = xy.getX();
291                final double y = xy.getY();
292                final double a = a00 * x + a01 * y + a02;       // = alpha
293                final double b = a10 * x + a11 * y + a12;       // = beta
294                final double c = a20 * x + a21 * y + 1;         // = gamma
295                if (Arithmetic.isZero(c)) {
296                        throw new ArithmeticException("getJacobian(): division by zero!");
297                }
298                final double cc = c * c;
299                return new double[][]
300                        {{x/c, y/c, 0,   0,   -(x*a)/cc, -(y*a)/cc, 1/c, 0  },
301                         {0,   0,   x/c, y/c, -(x*b)/cc, -(y*b)/cc, 0,   1/c}};
302        }
303        
304        // -----------------------------------------------------------------
305        
306        /**
307         * For testing only.
308         * @param args ignored
309         */
310        public static void main(String[] args) {
311                PrintPrecision.set(6);
312
313                // book example:
314                Pnt2d[] P = {
315                                PntDouble.from(2, 5),
316                                PntDouble.from(4, 6),
317                                PntDouble.from(7, 9),
318                                PntDouble.from(5, 9),
319                                PntDouble.from(5.2, 9.1)        // 5 points, overdetermined!
320                                };
321                
322                Pnt2d[] Q = {
323                                PntDouble.from(4, 3),
324                                PntDouble.from(5, 2),
325                                PntDouble.from(9, 3),
326                                PntDouble.from(7, 5),
327                                PntDouble.from(7, 4.9)  // 5 points, overdetermined!
328                                };
329                
330                ProjectiveMapping2D pm = ProjectiveMapping2D.fromPoints(P, Q);
331                
332                System.out.println("\nprojective mapping = \n" + pm.toString());
333                
334                for (int i = 0; i < P.length; i++) {
335                        Pnt2d Bi = pm.applyTo(P[i]);
336                        System.out.println(P[i].toString() + " -> " + Bi.toString());
337                }
338                
339                System.out.println("pm is of class " + pm.getClass().getName());
340                ProjectiveMapping2D pmi = pm.getInverse();
341                pmi = pmi.normalize();
342                System.out.println("\ninverse projective mapping (normalized) = \n" + pmi.toString());
343                
344                for (int i = 0; i < Q.length; i++) {
345                        Pnt2d Ai = pmi.applyTo(Q[i]);
346                        System.out.println(Q[i].toString() + " -> " + Ai.toString());
347                }
348                
349                ProjectiveMapping2D testId = pm.concat(pmi);
350                System.out.println("\ntest: should be a scaled identity matrix: = \n" + testId.toString());
351        }
352        /*
353         projective mapping = 
354        {{-0.732424, 1.208712, 0.244379}, 
355        {-1.702388, 1.725545, -1.654658}, 
356        {-0.206047, 0.123181, 1.000000}}
357        Point[2,000, 5,000] -> Point[4,007, 2,964]
358        Point[4,000, 6,000] -> Point[4,992, 2,065]
359        Point[7,000, 9,000] -> Point[8,999, 2,939]
360        Point[5,000, 9,000] -> Point[6,918, 4,973]
361        Point[5,200, 9,100] -> Point[7,084, 4,950]
362        pm is of class imagingbook.pub.geometry.mappings.linear.ProjectiveMapping2D
363        
364        inverse projective mapping (normalized) = 
365        {{2.430345, -1.484645, -3.050507}, 
366        {2.573894, -0.859176, -2.050649}, 
367        {0.183712, -0.200073, 1.000000}}
368        Point[4,000, 3,000] -> Point[1,954, 4,995]
369        Point[5,000, 2,000] -> Point[4,038, 5,993]
370        Point[9,000, 3,000] -> Point[6,998, 9,028]
371        Point[7,000, 5,000] -> Point[5,086, 9,078]
372        Point[7,000, 4,900] -> Point[5,122, 9,005]
373        
374        test: should be a scaled identity matrix: = 
375        {{1.000000, -0.000000, -0.000000}, 
376        {0.000000, 1.000000, -0.000000}, 
377        {0.000000, 0.000000, 1.000000}}
378         */
379}
